column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0008]In general, the wet-laid process for making fiber mats comprises first forming an aqueous slurry of short-length fibers, usually glass fibers (referred to in the art as "white water") under agitation in a mixing tank, then feeding the slurry onto a moving screen on which the fibers enmesh themselves into a freshly prepared wet fiber mat, while excess water is separated from the mat of fibers.
#Text=[0009]Machines such as wire cylinders, Fourdrinier machines, Stevens Former, Roto Former, Inver Former, Venti Former machines and the like can be used to form the wet-laid mat.
#Text=In such equipment, a head box deposits the slurry onto a moving wire screen.
#Text=Suction or vacuum removes the water resulting in the wet-laid mat.
#Text=[0010]Unlike natural fibers such as cellulose or asbestos, glass fibers and some synthetic fibers generally do not disperse well in water.
#Text=To overcome this problem, it has been the industry practice to provide suspending aids for the fibers.
#Text=Such suspending aids or dispersants usually are materials that increase the viscosity of the aqueous medium.
#Text=Suitable dispersants conventionally employed in the art include polyacrylamides, hydroxyethyl cellulose (HEC), carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), ethoxylated amines and amine oxides.
#Text=Other additives such as surfactants, lubricants and defoamers also conventionally have been added to the white water.
#Text=Such agents, for example, further aid the wettability and dispersion of the fibers.
#Text=Experience has shown that such additives also often influence the strength of the wet fiber mat.

#Text=[0011]The fiber slurry deposited on the moving screen or cylinder is processed into a sheet-like fiber mat by the removal of water, usually by suction and/or vacuum devices, and is followed by the application of an adhesive binder formulation to the mat.
#Text=In the manufacture of fiber mats, a high degree of flexibility and tear strength is desired in the finished mat in addition to primary dry tensile and wet tensile properties.
#Text=An adhesive binder formulation is therefore used to hold the fiber mat together.

#Text=The binder formulation is impregnated directly into the fibrous mat and set or cured immediately thereafter (usually by the application of heat by passing the mat through a drying oven) to provide the desired mat integrity.

#Text=[0012]The binder formulation is applied to the mat by soaking the mat in an excess of binder solution or suspension, or more usually by impregnating the mat with the adhesive binder formulation by means of a binder applicator, for example, by a roller coater, curtain coater, dip and squeeze applicator, or spray coater to name a few.
#Text=One of the primary binder applicators for conventional fiber mat machines has been the falling film curtain coater.
#Text=Suction devices often are also utilized for further removal of water and excess binder and to ensure a thorough application of binder through the full thickness of the fiber mat.
